projects.title: Conducting Water Sector Public Expenditure Reviews
projects.description:
The Governments of Kenya, Mozambique, and Nigeria asked the World Bank to conduct Public Expenditure Reviews (PER) of their water sectors. The PERs would be used to identify options to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of public sector spending and to better understand the role that public spending plays in achieving sector objectives.

Deborah oversaw the preparation of the water sector PERs. She facilitated data collection and exchange between DHInfrastructure's local and international teams and reviewed drafts of each project deliverable. She prepared Kenya's water sector PER, which involved preparing an overview of the country's institutional and policy framework, reviewing the sector's budgetary process, and budget allocations and expenditures. She analyzed sector allocation and expenditure trends by subsector, spending category, program, and government administration levels. She then assessed the targeting and relative efficiency of sector spending and estimated the funding, financing, and efficiency gaps in the sector up to 2030. Finally, she identified actionable recommendations for government to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of sector spending.

projects.title: Timor Leste Power Sector Adivsory on Options for Interim Generation Contract
projects.description:
Current operations and maintenance (O&M) contracts for Timor-Leste’s major diesel power plants (Hera, Betano, and Comoro); and O&M arrangements for the operation of the country’s transmission and dispatch system are coming to an end. DHInfrastructure was asked to review the current contractual arrangements and the options being contemplated by key counterpart stakeholders, and advise on most advantageous commercial options as a basis for conclusion of new interim O&M contracts with either (i) the incumbent O&M operators, or (ii) suitably qualified alternative O&M operators.

Deborah researched various approaches to contract and contract variation designs and examples of successful PPP arrangements in the power sector in other countries.

projects.title: Scaling Up Energy Efficiency Retrofit of Residential and Public Buildings
projects.description:
The World Bank had requested a report for the government of Belarus, for the recommendation of financing and delivery options for scaling-up energy efficiency investments in thermal retrofits and heating system upgrades in residential and public buildings. The assignment consists of four parts: 1.) a stocktaking of the legal, regulatory, and institutional environment and characteristics of the building sector including management, ownership, and financing procedures; 2.) an assessment of potential for energy efficiency improvements and investment needs; 3.) an analysis of the barriers and potential solutions to investment and 4.) development of a road map and areas for donor involvement.

As co-manager of the assignment, Deborah worked closely with the World Bank team to develop options for the financing and delivery of thermal retrofits to residential and public buildings. To this end she analysed current public financing arrangements, such as the flow of funds and researched alternative modes of public finance such as performance based budgeting and a budget capture mechanism to enable implementation agencies to retain savings from investments in energy efficiency.

projects.title: Regional Energy Sector Diagnostic Report for the Western Balkans
projects.description:
The energy landscape in the Western Balkans has been in a complex and challenging state in the past three decades and no clear systematic picture of those challenges currently exists. The objective of this project was to identify key energy issues and constraints which require country-specific and regionally-coordinated interventions in the Western Balkans.

Deborah conducted research and analysis to identify specific challenges to the energy sector in the Western Balkans. Her analysis focused specifically on renewable energy, energy efficiency and gas developments.

projects.title: Preparation of PPP ToR: Caribbean Regional Communications Infrastructure Project (CARCIP)
projects.description:
The Caribbean Telecommunications Union (CTU), with support of the World Bank, wanted to hire consultants for the design, preparation and implementation of a regionally-harmonized policy and institutional framework for open access and Public Private Partnerships (PPP). The CTU first needed a draft a terms of reference (ToR) which would ensure the consultants hired would have good knowledge of international practice in broadband PPPs, and would also develop an approach that recognized the unique national policies and circumstances in each of the countries of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS).

Deborah contributed to preparing the ToR by researching the CARCIP project and reviewing the PPP readiness for phase 1 participating countries of CARCIP, including Grenada, St. Lucia and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. She also assisted in drafting various section of the ToR

projects.title: Preparation of the SREP Investment Plan for Kiribati
projects.description:
The Government of Kiribati requested assistance in the preparation of an Investment Plan, which would be used to apply for renewable energy project funding through the Climate Investment Fund's Scaling Up Renewable Energy Program (SREP). The primary objective of the Investment Plan was to identify renewable energy projects where SREP resources and other sources of funds could be used to overcome barriers to investment.

Deborah managed the development of the Investment Plan. She led in-country consultations with development partners, civil society, and government agencies to identify energy sector challenges and develop a renewable energy investment program that addressed barriers to increasing renewable investment and socioeconomic needs of I-Kiribati. She drafted the Investment Plan and prepared the writeup of Kiribati’s renewable energy resource potential, the financial and economic viability of technically viable renewable energy technologies, and a program description of potential renewable energy projects for South Tarawa and Kiritimati.

projects.title: Preparation of Clean Energy Projects in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei Region
projects.description:
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) launched the Air Quality Improvement Program in the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region in 2015 as part of a multi-year, multi-sector effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and local air pollution. The program consists of several projects including (1) a green financing platform that acts as a financial intermediary to provide loans to businesses for renewable energy and energy efficiency investments; (2) financing to deploy high-technology (such as hydrogen-powered buses, smart grids, and coke gasification) to reduce pollution from transport, agriculture, and industry; (3) investment in advanced heating and cooling technologies such as waste heat utilization, geothermal district heating, and ice storage to reduce coal use; and (4) investment in a natural gas and biogas infrastructure to displace coal use. ADB was looking for a consultant to assist with project documentation and to conduct an economic and financial analysis of each component of the projects.

Deborah prepared the project report and recommendations to ADB’s Board of Directors. She also prepared economic analyses of several subprojects eligible for financing.

projects.title: Water Tariff and Affordability Study in Arusha, Tanzania
projects.description:
The Arusha Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Authority (AUWSA) wanted to conduct a tariff and willingness-to-pay study as part of an African Development Bank (AfDB) funded project to improve and expand the water and sanitation network in Arusha City. The two components of the project included a cost-of-service study and a willingness-to-pay study. For the of the cost-of-service study, AUWSA wanted a financial model that they could use for future tariff filings to the water sector regulator. They also wanted the model to allow them to forecast the impact of increased debt service on its financial performance and tariff levels. AUWSA wanted a willingness-to-pay study to understand how much they could charge for new water connections and septic tank vacuum truck services.

Deborah managed the willingness-to-pay component of the assignment. She developed the survey instrument and recruited and trained a team of enumerators and a survey supervisor to administer the survey. She also worked with the local team to pretest the survey. Deborah also developed a questionnaire and outline to guide the local team in facilitating focus group discussions. She contributed to the preparation of the inception, draft final, and final reports.

projects.title: Terminal Evaluation of the GEF-funded Geofund Turkey Project
projects.description:
The International Finance Corporation (IFC) wanted an external evaluation of the Global Environmental Facility (GEF)-funded Geofund Turkey Project, which aimed to promote private sector geothermal energy development by developing and piloting geothermal well productivity insurance (GWPI) and by providing capacity building to developers and to financial institutions. The objectives of the evaluation were to elaborate on and synthesize the lessons learned from the project to help improve the selection, design, and implementation of future GEF and IFC activities and to assess the potential and scope for future IFC interventions to address barriers to private sector geothermal development in Turkey and other countries.

Deborah evaluated the Geofund Turkey Project’s progress toward priorities, objectives and targets; its operations and processes; and its approach to developing and piloting GWPI in Turkey’s geothermal market. She interviewed project stakeholders and evaluated the project using the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development’s Development Assistance Committee (OECD/DAC) criteria of relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, impact, and sustainability. She evaluated the lessons IFC learned from the project, identified additional lessons that can inform IFC’s advisory services in the energy sector, and identified the framework conditions and factors that determine financing arrangements for early stage geothermal investments.

projects.title: Preparation of SREP Investment Plan for Lesotho
projects.description:
The Government of Lesotho requested assistance in the preparation of an Investment Plan , which would be used to apply for renewable energy project funding through the Climate Investment Fund’s Scaling Up Renewable Energy Program (SREP). The primary objective of the Investment Plan was to identify renewable energy projects where SREP resources and other sources of funds could be used to overcome barriers to investment.

Deborah managed the development of the Investment Plan, including the comprehensive assessment of potential renewable energy projects in Lesotho. As part of this assessment, she built a financial model for calculating the levelized energy costs of each renewable energy option and used this analysis in conjunction with an economic and social impact evaluation of each option to develop a priority ranking of renewable energy projects. She drafted the Investment Plan, which identified specific investment opportunities and potential sources of funding for each opportunity.

projects.title: Timor Leste District Capitals Water Tariff Study
projects.description:
The Government of Timor Leste has committed to providing a safe, 24-hour piped water supply to all urban households by 2030 under the country’s Strategic Development Plan 2011-2030. Achieving this objective will require not only substantial investment in rehabilitating and expanding water supply systems, but will require on-going investments in operations and maintenance to ensure sustained improvements in water supply services. As part of this plan, the Ministry of Public Works Transport and Communications (MOPTC) is preparing a new National Water Supply Policy and revising tariff rates. DHInfrastructure was hired to i) review the Water Services Tariff Policy, ii) confirm that the principles for tariff setting are appropriate, iii) review tariff structure and rates and iv) provide adjustments to ensure that rates are consistent with tariff policy objectives and principles.

Deborah reviewed the draft National Policy on Public Water Supply, ADB technical assistance reports on recent projects to improve the water supply systems in Dili and the district capitals and recent socio-economic surveys conducted in the country. She then traveled to Timor Leste to meet with stakeholders to discuss the proposed tariff principles and collect additional data necessary to building the tariff model. Finally, she and the DHInfrastructure team prepared the financial model which considered various tariff options for Dili and the district capitals. The analysis considered the affordability of new tariffs under various scenarios as well as possible alternative pro-poor measures to protect the vulnerable population.

projects.title: EBRD Ukraine PPP Policy Statement
projects.description:
The Government of Ukraine asked the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) to harmonize its legal and regulatory framework for PPPs with the European Union Concessions Directive. As part of this effort, the Government, together with EBRD, wanted to develop a PPP Policy Statement.

Deborah contributed to the preparation of the PPP policy statement. The policy statement defined the objectives and characteristics of PPPs/concessions in the Ukraine, general principles for the design and structuring of PPPs, stages of project preparation for PPPs, principles for the appraisal of PPP projects, principles for the PPP procurement and financing, and general approaches to contract monitoring, oversight, reporting and evaluation of PPP projects.

projects.title: Contingent Valuation Study (Willingness to Pay) for Water Supply and Solid Waste Management Services in Dili, Timor Leste
projects.description:
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is providing a grant to the Government of Timor Leste for the Dili Urban Services Improvement Sector Project. As part of the proposed investment project, ADB asked DHInfrastructure to conduct a contingent valuation study to assess household willingness to pay for improved water supply and solid waste disposal services. The analysis was used to determine if financially sustainable tariff levels are in line with willingness to pay for service improvements.

Deborah served as Project Manager of the assignment. As part of her work, she was part of the team which developed the contingent valuation study (willingness-to-pay). She then traveled to Timor Leste for a scoping visit and conducted focus group discussions and prepared the local team to administer the survey through training, piloting and survey kick-off phases. .

projects.title: Armenia Water Tariffs Study
projects.description:
Water and wastewater tariffs in Armenia are very low and do not cover operating and maintenance (O&M) expenditures or provide sufficient funds to adequately deal with asset rehabilitation. Consequently, there are looming concerns about the long-term sustainability of service provision by existing public-private partnership (PPP) arrangements. The World Bank Group (WBG) requested assistance in developing a water sector tariff study for Armenia to assess the levels of the current water and wastewater tariffs in terms of cost-recovery. The World Bank wanted a description of a number of tariff scenarios, taking into account financial, economic, efficiency and equity objectives. Lastly, a plan of actions would be developed to move from the current tariff levels and structure to an agreed future tariff level and structure.

Deborah prepared the affordability and willingness to pay components of the assignment. She helped develop the survey which used the contingent valuation stated preference method. She analysed the results of the survey and reported the findings in the final report. For the affordability section of the study, Deborah calculated the maximum threshold of affordability by various sub groups such as the poor and non-poor. This was conducted using estimated 2012 household expenditures, average water consumption. The results were also projected to 2030, adjusted by % GDP growth, and price elasticity of demand for water. The results will enable the government of Armenia to introduce appropriate mitigation measures if water tariffs (prices) are above the affordability threshold. Finally, Deborah also assisted in building parts of the tariff model. She built a segment of the model which enables the user to determine each tariff block necessary to cover sector costs by customer class.

projects.title: Options for Power Sector Reform in Timor Leste
projects.description:
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) wanted to present to Government a series of reform options for Timor Leste’s power sector. This required: i) the examination of the current policy, legal and regulatory framework in the country’s power sector, including the contractual arrangements with the private sector; ii) an identification of options for unbundling the sector, introducing competition, and introducing additional public private partnerships; iii) consultation with stakeholders on their preferred option, and iv) recommendation of the option most suitable for Timor Leste.

Deborah analyzed the power sector of Timor Leste and prepared the first draft of the SWOT options report and presentation. She also prepared the presentation evaluating the performance of the electricity operator in Timor Leste, EDTL. She was part of the team which researched and wrote the final reform options report.

projects.title: Kyrgyzstan Energy Tariffs: Revision of Electricity and District Heating Tariff Methodology and Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
projects.description:
The Kyrgyz Republic needed a well-defined methodology for setting power and heating tariffs. The World Bank asked DHInfrastructure to support the Ministry of Energy of the Kyrgyz Republic in establishing a sustainable, transparent and equitable tariff setting methodology aimed at ensuring cost-recovery, and improved transparency and accountability.

Deborah analyzed the key performance indicators of the power sector in Kyrgyzstan and then presented international best practice performance indicators used by electricity regulators in the United States, United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia.

projects.title: Belarus Heat Tariff Reform and Social Impact Mitigation
projects.description:
Belarus relies heavily on imported energy resources (mostly natural gas from Russia) to meet domestic energy demand. In 2009, the cost of natural gas imports constituted 5.2 percent of GDP. While still below the European market prices, import prices of natural gas have been increasing sharply over the last 5 years, as a result, the cost of district heating services has also increased increasing the fiscal burden to the government. The objective of this project was to understand the incidence of current energy subsidies in Belarus, to estimate the poverty and social impacts of proposed tariff and subsidies reform, and to identify and strengthen mechanisms to mitigate negative impacts of tariff increases.

The World Bank asked DHInfrastructure to analyze the district heating sector of Belarus. To this end, DHInfrastructure examined the legal and institutional framework, and national energy programs related to the district heating sector as well as the current performance and tariff structure of the sector. In addition, DHInfrastructure wrote the final report that incorporated all tasks related to this project, including the social and stakeholder analyses and energy efficiency components.

projects.title: Evaluation of the New Deal on Energy for Africa (NDEA)
projects.description:
The Independent Development Evaluation (IDEV) unit of the African Development Bank (AfDB) wanted to evaluate the New Deal on Energy For Africa (NDEA), which aimed to achieve universal access to energy by 2025 through increasing on- and off-grid generation, exanding transmission lines, providing access to clean cooking energy, and leveraging public and private resources to solve Africa's energy challenges. Specifically, IDEV wanted to evaluate the quality at entry of the NDEA Strategy, benchmark the NDEA against other major energy initiatives in the region, and develop country case studies to assess ecosystems-based factors to the success or failure of the NDEA's implementation.

Deborah benchmarked the NDEA strategy against comparator strategies from the World Bank, Power Africa, and Agence Franaise de Dveloppement to identify elements that characterize good, effective strategies at multilateral development banks. She analyzed donor reports from each strategy qualitatively using Atlas.ti to evaluate their logical framework, results monitoring framework, and level of commited and available resources (human and financial). Based on this analysis, Deborah scored each strategy and identified areas for improvement that AfDB could adopt in its NDEA strategy. She summarized her analysis in the benchmarking report.

projects.title: SECO Albania Energy Sector Cooperation Strategy for 2018 to 2021
projects.description:
The State Secretariat for Economic Affairs (SECO) has provided grant-funded infrastructure and technical assistance to the Albanian energy sector since 1992. SECO wanted assistance in planning its activities in the sector for 2018 to 2021. They asked specifically for an elaboration of specific areas of possible intervention, project opportunities, and potential performance monitoring indicators that would contribute towards the further development of Albania’s energy sector.

Deborah interviewed Government, private sector, and donor stakeholders during a scoping mission to Tirana; identified key challenges facing the Albanian energy sector; and researched ongoing and planned interventions by donors and government. Based on the mission's findings, Deborah prepared a scoping study report which identified and elaborated on potential project opportunities for Swiss cooperation in the 2018–2021 planning period.
